intro: Hieracium lachenalii subsp. meppelense, commonly known as the Meppel hawkweed, is a flowering plant native to parts of Europe, particularly the Netherlands. It belongs to the family Asteraceae and is characterized by its basal rosette of leaves and yellow composite flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, calcareous soils and is often found in meadows and along riverbanks. It is a perennial species with a low-growing habit, and its leaves are usually hairy and lance-shaped. Due to its limited distribution, it is considered a rare and protected species in some regions.
